title: AB 2025
content: The State of California enacts the following. The State of California enacts Section 7312 of the Business and Professions Code, which outlines the responsibilities of the board, including making rules, conducting examinations, issuing licenses, and disciplining violators. The State of California enacts Section 7312 of the Business and Professions Code, outlining the board's responsibilities. Section 7314 is also amended to include rules on sanitary conditions, language accessibility, and effective date of July 1, 2017. Section 7314 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require the board to keep records of its proceedings, licensee information, and language preferences. The amendments will be effective on July 1, 2017. The Business and Professions Code is amended to establish a Health and Safety Advisory Committee to advise the board on health and safety issues impacting licensees, including labor laws awareness. The amendments will be effective on July 1, 2017. Section 7337 of the Business and Professions Code is amended to require written applications for examination and licensure on board-provided forms. Each application for examination and licensure must be accompanied by the required fee, proof of qualifications, and verification by oath. Applicants must acknowledge their rights as licensees and provide proof of identification at the examination facility. Every electronic license renewal application must include a signed acknowledgment of the licensee's rights as outlined in labor law materials provided by the board. Amendments to this section will be effective on July 1, 2017. Any person, firm, or corporation must apply for a license from the bureau to operate an establishment, accompanied by the prescribed fee. The application includes an acknowledgment of compliance with state labor laws and informational materials provided by the board. Renewal applications also require an acknowledgment of labor law compliance. The applicant must understand state labor laws and informational materials provided by the board when applying for a license. The license authorizes operation only at the specified location, and obtaining ownership of an existing establishment may have a reduced fee. The license authorizes operation at a specified location, and a new location can be obtained upon compliance with the section for issuing a license. The board will develop a health and safety course on hazardous substances and labor laws to be taught in approved schools, with amendments becoming effective on July 1, 2017.
